children.subject: hmm yeah that is a good point. I guess the thought of going straight into the working world doesn't really excite me all that much right now, but I should probably start applying over the summer regardless to see what doors are open for me

Not in any position to advise, but why wouldn't you focus on getting a job first, setting that worry aside, and then going traveling until your job's official start date? Curious to see your perspective, since i'm perpetually worried about my professional future.

I'm curious about what sort of career you see yourself pursuing. A lot of the people I've talked to about post-graduation plans seem to assume they'll work in SWE forever and continue to find it fulfilling, and while working to live is fine, I'm sure most of us can benefit from some intense thinking about what goals to pursue professionally. This doesn't have to happen in academic setting. Travelling like you suggested is perfectly valid. But if you're not sure you'll want to do SWE or some other career path you're already prepared for, I think you should stay and try to take grad classes in something you genuinely find interesting, because most of these classes by virtue of being useful to PhD students have to be at the edge of their fields. If you've finished the EECS prereqs you're probably really well prepared for a typical high-paying job in industry but I think life would be a lot more fulfilling if you could work in a niche area that you can help push forward.

I'm in the same boat, I think recruiting-wise most new grad hiring is over in the Fall, so doesn't hurt to graduate early in that sense. If it saves you a lot of money then you should consider graduating early, but also depends on if you're able to secure a job by that time and if you have a plan for that time off (which it seems like you do).

"to finally enjoy life" sad.

Follow your gut feeling.

In the grand scheme of life, what you do next year doesn't really matter. Working, traveling, doing nothing, taking grad courses. It really depends on your goals and interests. Someone really interested in going to grad school, I might advise to take the grad courses and do more research. Someone who wants to see the world but hasn't, i'd say go see the world.

In general, you can take time off using PTO, or between jobs, or just by quitting a job, but the best time to travel is anytime before starting work.

It doesn't sound like you have financial aid, and idk how much you enjoy being at Cal, but if it were me, i'd graduate with a reduced load(1 class), and just travel as much as possible and work on myself physically, mentally, and skills for my career. Get a full time job first, then travel a lot.

history.content:
I'm a junior, and as I was filling out my degree check for EECS, I noticed that I just need one more class to graduate, an UD design course. My three options are: (1) take two full semesters, probably with graduate courses, (2) take one full semester, hopefully with one grad course, graduate next sem, (3) just take an UD design course and graduate next semester with a reduced course load.

If I graduate early, I would save a lot of money and probably use some of my time / extra money to finally enjoy life and go traveling (I probably wouldn't want to go STRAIGHT into work so I wouldn't get the recruiting advantages of graduating early).

I was wondering if anyone had any advice or is in a similar position? Really not sure what to do!

Thanks!
history.subject: Graduating Early
